description: Potato is a widely cultivated root vegetable rich in carbohydrates, vitamins C and B6, potassium, and dietary fiber. It is a staple food in many cultures and used in various culinary dishes such as fries, stews, soups, and curries.

soil.type: Well-drained, sandy or loamy soil with high organic matter

climate.watering: Water regularly but avoid waterlogging, especially during tuber formation. Use drip irrigation to prevent leaf wetting.

symptoms: Dark brown or black spots with concentric rings, often forming a target-like pattern on leaves
Yellowing of leaves around spots, leading to defoliation
Reduced tuber growth and yield due to decreased photosynthesis

background.cause: Fungal pathogen *Alternaria solani*, which thrives in warm and humid conditions.
background.spread_by: Contaminated soil, infected plant debris, rain splash, and wind.

cure: Apply fungicides such as Mancozeb or Chlorothalonil early in the season to manage infection.
Use organic treatments like neem oil or copper-based fungicides as preventive measures.
Avoid overhead watering to reduce leaf wetness and prevent fungal growth.
Remove and dispose of infected plant material to reduce fungal spores in the environment.
Apply fungicides periodically, especially during warm and humid conditions.
diseases.fertilizers: Use balanced fertilizers high in potassium to strengthen plant resistance. Avoid excess nitrogen, which may increase susceptibility to fungal infections.
prevention: Space plants adequately for good air circulation and to minimize humidity levels around foliage.
Mulch the base of plants to prevent soil splashing that may spread fungal spores.
Practice crop rotation to avoid planting potatoes or tomatoes in the same area year after year.
Remove any plant debris after the growing season to eliminate potential sources of fungal spores.
Monitor plants regularly and remove affected leaves at the first sign of infection.

symptoms: Large, dark, water-soaked lesions on leaves and stems
White fungal growth under the leaves during humid conditions
Tuber rot with brown, granular patches extending through the flesh

background.cause: Fungus-like pathogen *Phytophthora infestans*, which spreads rapidly in cool, moist conditions.
background.spread_by: Wind, rain splash, and infected seed tubers.

cure: Apply fungicides such as Metalaxyl or Mancozeb at the onset of symptoms.
Remove and destroy infected plants to prevent disease spread.
Spray fungicides at regular intervals during rainy periods to protect healthy plants.
Ensure thorough soil drainage to prevent waterlogging around the plant roots.
Regularly disinfect tools and equipment after working with infected plants to prevent contamination.
diseases.fertilizers: Apply fertilizers high in potassium and low in nitrogen to boost plant immunity and improve resilience against blight.
prevention: Plant disease-resistant varieties when available for your region.
Space plants to ensure good air circulation, reducing the likelihood of moisture accumulation.
Avoid overhead watering and water at the base to prevent fungal spores from splashing onto foliage.
Rotate crops yearly and avoid planting potatoes or tomatoes in the same soil for at least two years.
Dispose of all plant debris away from the garden to avoid overwintering of pathogens in the soil.
Use certified disease-free seed potatoes to prevent initial infection and spread.

preventive_practices: Rotate crops to avoid buildup of soil-borne pathogens
Apply mulch to reduce soil splashing and conserve moisture
Use drip irrigation to keep leaves dry and prevent fungal infections
Space plants for optimal air circulation
Remove and destroy infected plant material to prevent disease spread
